revision.text:
'''José Carlos Brunoro''' ([[Santo André]], 11 June 1950), commonly known as '''Brunoro''', was the CEO of [[Palmeiras]], one of Brazil's largest soccer teams, and the co-founder of [[Grêmio Osasco Audax Esporte Clube]]. He has over 40 years of experience in professional sports in a plethora of positions: professional athlete, trainer, coach, sports executive, sports marketing consultant, appointed member of the national council for sports (CNE) by Brazil’s ministry of sports, among others. Brunoro held executive positions in different professional sports such as [[volleyball]], [[soccer]], [[Formula One]], and [[basketball]]. ==Palmeiras== Between 1992 and 1996, Brunoro was a soccer executive at [[Palmeiras]] and signed young players like [[Rivaldo]], [[Roberto Carlos]], who are now recognized as some of the best of all times. On June 12 1993, Palmeiras won the São Paulo championship, beating the rival Corinthians 4x0 in the final. The last major title that the club had won was in 1976, 17 years prior to that one. [http://www.lance.com.br/palmeiras/torcedores-verdao-contam-suas-historias-sobre-junho-1993.html Torcedores do Verdão contam suas histórias sobre 12 de junho de 1993, Lance! 14 de junho de 1993] In January 2013, Brunoro became the CEO of [[Palmeiras]],[http://esportes.estadao.com.br/noticias/futebol,por-profissionalizacao-brunoro-sera-ceo-no-palmeiras,987843 Por Profissionalização, Brunoro será CEO no Palmeiras - Estadão.com 23/01/2013]Brazil’s fourth largest team with over 10 million fans. [http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/esporte/2014/08/1494430-um-em-cada-tres-torce-para-flamengo-ou-corinthians-aponta-datafolha.shtml Um em cada Três torce para Flamengo ou Corinthians, aponta Datafolha - Folha de São Paulo 1 de Agosto de 2014] In the beginning of his mandate as CEO, in January 2013, Brunoro ended speculations about bringing Argentine superstar [[Juan Román Riquelme]] to play for [[Palmeiras]].[http://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/times/palmeiras/noticia/2013/01/palmeiras-desiste-de-riquelme-nao-podemos-nos-dar-ao-luxo-diz-nobre.html Palmeiras desiste de Riquelme. 'Não podemos nos dar ao luxo', diz Nobre - Globoesporte.com 24/01/2013] The club tried to hire Argentine head coach [[Marcelo Bielsa]], who refused to join Palmeiras.[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2013-11-13/content_10575690.html Bielsa turns down offer to coach Brazil's Palmeiras, Chinadaily 13 de Novembro de 2013] In December 2014, it was announced that Brunoro would no longer be [[Palmeiras]] CEO.[http://esporte.uol.com.br/futebol/ultimas-noticias/2014/12/23/palmeirense-ainda-vai-me-agradecer-avisa-brunoro-apos-saida-do-palmeiras.htm "Palmeirense vai me agradecer", diz Brunoro após deixar Palmeiras, UolEsportes 23 de Dezembro de 2014"] ==Audax== In 2003, Brunoro co-founded Audax with [[Abilio Diniz]] and Fernando Solleiro. {{Cite web |url=http://esportes.terra.com.br/palmeiras/algoz-de-100-do-palmeiras-nasceu-sob-ordens-de-brunoro-veja-entrevista,71586ba63d124410VgnVCM4000009bcceb0aRCRD.html# |title=Algoz de 100% do Palmeiras nasceu sob ordens de Brunoro, veja entrevista - TerraEsportes 11 de Fevereiro de 2014 |access-date=2016-05-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160531160134/http://esportes.terra.com.br/palmeiras/algoz-de-100-do-palmeiras-nasceu-sob-ordens-de-brunoro-veja-entrevista,71586ba63d124410VgnVCM4000009bcceb0aRCRD.html# |archive-date=2016-05-31 |dead-url=yes |df= }} From 2003 to 2013, Brunoro led Audax. He left the project to become CEO of Palmeiras.[http://espn.uol.com.br/noticia/305970_jose-carlos-brunoro-dividira-atencao-entre-palmeiras-e-os-x-games Jose Carlos Brunoro dividirá atenção entre Palmeiras e os X Games, ESPN.com.br 25 de Janeiro de 2013] Audax, led by Brunoro, organized tryouts for about 70 thousand players to select athletes.[http://www.sindicatodeatletas.com.br/?pg=noticias&id=377 Pão de Açúcar, da Série A-2, tem novo nome. Confira, Sindicato de Atletas de São Paulo 18 de Julho de 2011]
In 2016, Audax reached the final of São Paulo Championship, eliminating São Paulo in the quarter finals 4x1, and Corinthians in the semi-final at Corinthians home, where the team had won all its 12 matches in 2016.[http://globoesporte.globo.com/sp/futebol/campeonato-paulista/noticia/2016/05/em-osasco-santos-e-audax-comecam-disputa-pelo-titulo-do-paulistao-2016.html, Em Osasco Santos e Audax Comecam Disputa Pelo Titulo do Paulistao 2016, Globoesporte.com 01 de Maio de 2016]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Other Professional Sports Projects== Brunoro was a professional volleyball player, trainer, assistant coach, and head coach. For seven years, he was a trainer. As part of the coaching staff, Brazil's volleyball national team won silver medal in the summer Olympics in 1984 in Los Angeles.[http://esportes.estadao.com.br/noticias/volei,a-medalha-de-prata-em-1984-virou-ouro-para-o-futuro-do-volei-brasileiro,1541939.brunoro.com.br/?pg=biografia, Estado de Sao Paulo 11 de Agosto de 2014]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} During six years, between 1996 and 2002, he was an executive in [[Formula One]], managing the career of racer [[Pedro Paulo Diniz]] in teams Ligier, Arrows, and Sauber. [http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/esporte/fk250537.htm, A formula 1 é mais dificil, Folha de São Paulo 25 de Maio de 1997]
He was the co-author of the book Soccer 100% professional, launched in 1997 by publisher Gente. [https://books.google.com/books?isbn=8573121491 Futebol 100% profissional], José Carlos Brunoro, Antonio Afif - 1997 - Editora Gente.
In 2004, he was appointed member of national council for sports (CNE) of Brazil’s ministry of sports.[http://www.esporte.gov.br/index.php/institucional/futebol-e-direitos-do-torcedor/futebol-feminino/2013-12-09-13-05-27/86-ministerio-do-esporte/institucional/conselhoEsporte/reuniao1130802.jsp, Comunicado do Ministério do Esporte 29 de Julho de 2003]
In 2009, he was named technical director of Brazil’s confederation of basketball. In 2011, Brazil men’s basketball national team qualified for the summer Olympics after 16 years. [http://mais.uol.com.br/view/41fifddbrlez/basquete-masculino-brunoro-fala-sobre-o-rumo-as-olimpiadas-0402CD183264C4893326?types=A&, Basquete Masculino: Brunoro fala sobre o rumo às Olimpíadas, Band Sports 12 de Setembro de 2011]
He founded BSB (Brunoro Sports Business) in 1997. The company specializes in consulting in sports marketing and participated in the organization of X-Games in Foz do Iguaçu, south of Brazil.[http://www.esporte.pr.gov.br/modules/noticias/article.php?storyid=4124, Prefeito de Foz assina contrato para realização dos X-Games, Site do Governo do Estado do Paraná 26 de Fevereiro de 2013] In May 2016, Brunoro was announced as [[San Francisco Deltas]] consulting general manager. Brunoro’s primary responsibilities include building the new pro soccer team's soccer philosophy and recruiting technical staff and players. [http://blog.sfgate.com/soccer/2016/05/06/san-francisco-deltas-announce-brazilian-sports-executive-jose-carlos-brunoro-as-general-manager-nasl/, San Francisco Deltas announce Brazilian Sports Executive as General Manager, SF Gate 6th of May 2016]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brunoro, Jose Carlos}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Brazilian businesspeople]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
A '''legal nurse consultant''' ('''LNC''') is a [[registered nurse]] who uses expertise as a [[health care provider]] and specialized [[training]] to consult on medical-related [[legal case]]s. LNCs assist [[Lawyer|attorneys]] in reading [[medical record]]s and understanding medical terminology and [[healthcare]] issues to achieve the best results for their clients.<ref name=whatis>[http://www.aalnc.org/?page=WhatisanLNC "What is an LNC?"] on the AALNC website</ref> The specialty is a relatively recent one, beginning in the mid-1980s.<ref name=nyt />
A legal nurse consultant bridges gaps in an attorney's knowledge. While the attorney is an expert on legal issues, the LNC is an expert on [[nursing]] and the health care system. LNCs screen cases for merit, assist with [[Discovery (law)|discovery]]; conduct the existing literature and [[Biomedical research|medical research]]; review medical records; identify [[Standard of care|standards of care]]; prepare reports and summaries on the extent of injury or illness; create [[demonstrative evidence]]; and locate or act as [[expert witness]]es. The legal nurse consultant acts as a specialized member of the [[litigation]] team whose professional contributions are often critical to achieving a fair and just outcome for all parties.<ref name=whatis />
A legal nurse consultant differs from a [[paralegal]] in that a paralegal assists attorneys in the delivery of legal services and frequently requires a [[legal education]], while a legal nurse consultant is first and foremost a practictioner of nursing, and legal education is not necessarily a prerequisite. A legal nurse consultant uses existing expertise as a health care professional to consult and educate clients on specific medical and nursing issues in their cases.
Aside from within law firms, LNCs may also be found working for government agencies, insurance companies and [[HMO]]s, in hospitals as part of the [[risk management]] department, and may also be in independent practice.<ref name=whatis />
The [[American Association of Legal Nurse Consultants]] (AALNC), which was founded in 1989, is a non-profit membership organization whose mission is to promote legal nurse consulting as a nursing speciality.<ref>[http://www.aalnc.org/?page=MissionStatement "Mission and Goals"] on the AALNC website</ref> The Association also promulgates a Code of Ethics for the Legal Nurse Consultant practitioner.<ref>[http://www.aalnc.org/resource/resmgr/becoming_a_lnc_page/codeofethicsupdated2009final.pdf "Codes of Ethics"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} on the AALNC website</ref> As of 2001, the Association had approximately 4,000 members, the majority of whom had joined after 1994.<ref name=nyt />
There are a number of training courses and [[certification]]s available for LNCs. The American Legal Nurse Consultant Certification Board offers an online examination which is the only LNC certification exam credited by the [[American Board of Nursing Specialties]].<ref>[http://www.aalnc.org/page/LNCC/? "LNCC"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630034242/http://www.aalnc.org/page/LNCC/ |date=2012-06-30 }} on the AALNC website</ref> Other training and certification programs are available from both commercial and non-commercial organizations.<ref name=nyt /> As of 2001, the [[American Bar Association]] sanctioned 28 LNC programs across the United States.<ref name=nyt>{{cite news |last= Murphy |first= Kate |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/18/business/18PROF.html |title= Private sector: From hospital to law office |newspaper= New York Times |date= February 18, 2001}}</ref>
==See also== *{{Portal-inline|Nursing}}
== References == '''Notes''' {{Reflist}} {{refimprove|date=June 2012}}
<!--spacing-->
{{Nursing|state=collapsed}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Legal Nurse Consultant}} [[Category:Nursing specialties]] [[Category:Consulting occupations]] [[Category:Legal professions]]

revision.comment: /* Schools */
revision.text:
{{multiple image |footer=IFIM Business School campus in Bangalore (''left''), the School of Accountancy at [[Singapore Management University]] (''middle''), and Leventhal School of Accounting of the [[University of Southern California]] (''right'') |width1={{#expr: (120 * 800 / 524) round 0}} |image1=IFIM Campus in Bangalore.jpg |alt1=IFIM Business School campus in Bangalore |width2={{#expr: (120 * 1200 / 1600) round 0}} |image2=Singapore Management University 5, Aug 06.JPG |alt2=An exterior shot of a building with a metal-and-glass exterior. |width3={{#expr: (120 * 3264 / 2448) round 0}} |image3=Leventhal2012.JPG |alt3=An exterior shot of a red brick building behind several trees.}} [[File:AACSB Accredited.svg|thumbnail|Logo of accredited schools]] There are 182 schools that hold the [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business|Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business's]] (AACSB) [[Accounting]] [[Accreditation]]. The AACSB accredits [[business school]]s by evaluating critical areas of each school to ensure that it provides top-quality education,<ref name="AACSB Accreditation">{{cite web|title=Accreditation|url=http://www.aacsb.edu/accreditation/aacsb.asp|publisher=AACSB International}}</ref> and schools can apply for the [[accounting]] accreditation, which focusses on the schools' accounting programs, in addition to business accreditation.<ref name="AACSB Accounting">{{cite web|title=Accounting Accreditation|url=http://www.aacsb.edu/accreditation/accounting/|publisher=AACSB International|accessdate=19 January 2014|date=9 April 2013}}</ref>
Accreditation is gained and maintained via a peer-review system, and schools are assessed in the context of their respective missions rather than against a fixed standard.<ref name="WSJ 2013">{{cite web|last=Korn|first=Melissa|title=B-School Accrediting Body Retools Standards|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887323820304578411071717286236|work=The Wall Street Journal|publisher=Dow Jones & Company, Inc.|accessdate=19 January 2014|date=9 April 2013}}</ref> To apply for accounting accreditation, a school is required either to already hold the business accreditation, or to apply for both the business and accounting accreditations at the same time.<ref name="AACSB Accounting" />
The initial accounting accreditation process starts with the submission of an eligibility application, and includes self-evaluations and peer reviews.<ref name="AACSB Accounting" /> The business school and the accounting academic unit are evaluated on their alignment with the AACSB's accreditation standards; under the standard for accounting accreditation, an accounting academic unit is evaluated based on its mission, intellectual contributions, and financial strategies for achieving its mission. For example, one of the bases of evaluation is whether the academic unit has produced intellectual contributions that have affected [[accounting]], [[business]] and [[management]] "in ways that are consistent with the mission, expected outcomes, and strategies of the unit".<ref>{{cite web|title=Eligibility Procedures and Accreditation Standards for Accounting Accreditation |url=http://www.aacsb.edu/accreditation/accounting/standards/2013/2013-aacsb-accounting-accreditation-standards.pdf |publisher=AACSB |accessdate=22 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131108093650/http://aacsb.edu/accreditation/accounting/standards/2013/2013-aacsb-accounting-accreditation-standards.pdf |archivedate= 8 November 2013 |df= }}</ref> Subsequently, the accounting accreditation is extended via 5-year review cycles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Handbook For Joint Business And Accounting Continuous Improvement Reviews |url=http://www.aacsb.edu/accreditation/docs/Handbooks/2013/Continuous%20Improvement%20Review%20Handbook%20for%20Business%20and%20Accounting%20Reviews%202013%20FINAL%2020130619.pdf |publisher=AACSB |accessdate=22 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201175301/http://www.aacsb.edu/accreditation/docs/Handbooks/2013/Continuous%20Improvement%20Review%20Handbook%20for%20Business%20and%20Accounting%20Reviews%202013%20FINAL%2020130619.pdf |archivedate= 1 February 2014 |df= }}</ref>
As of 2013, the AACSB estimated that 5% of all business programs internationally, and most top business programs in the [[United States]], held AACSB accreditation.<ref name="WSJ 2013" /> AACSB accreditation is seen as a standard requirement in graduate business education, and universities are more likely to accept [[transfer credit]] earned from accredited schools;<ref name="HK 2003">{{cite journal|last=Hilpert|first=Ditmar|author2=Thomas Kern |title=Success Factors of American Business Schools or "How Business Schools Attract Promising Students"|journal=Applied Marketing|year=2003|pages=995–1012|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-642-18981-4_87|accessdate=19 January 2014}}</ref> it has been called "the hallmark of excellence in business education".<ref name=SMU>{{cite web|title=SMU is one of the youngest universities to receive accreditation from oldest global accrediting body AACSB International|url=http://www.smu.edu.sg/news/2011/04/11/smu-one-youngest-universities-receive-accreditation-oldest-global-accrediting-body|publisher=Singapore Management University|accessdate=19 January 2014}}</ref>

page.title: List of bicycle part manufacturing companies

revision.comment: rm non-notable: editors are encouraged to [[WP:WTAF|write the article first]]
revision.text:
This page lists [[bicycle]] part manufacturers and brands past and present. For a list of bicycle manufacturers, see [[list of bicycle manufacturers]].
{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}} <!-- Reminder: a name that is also a common word will link to the page for that common word unless disambiguated -->

==C== *[[Campagnolo]] *[[Centurion (bicycle)|Centurion]] *[[Cheng Shin Rubber]] (also branded as [[Cheng Shin Rubber#Maxxis|Maxxis]] and CST) *[[Cinelli]] *[[Coker Tire]] *[[Continental AG|Continental]] *[[Cannondale Bicycle Corporation]]

==L==

==Q== *[[Quality Bicycle Products]]
==R== * [[Raleigh Bicycle Company]] * [[Reynolds Technology]] * [[Ridley (bicycles)|Ridley]] * [[Tom Ritchey]] * [[RockShox]] – owned by [[SRAM Corporation]] * [[Rohloff AG]]
==S== *[[SRAM Corporation#Sachs Bicycle Components|Sachs]] *[[Schwalbe (tire manufacturer)|Schwalbe]] *[[Shimano]] *[[Specialized Bicycle Components]] *[[Speedplay (bicycle pedal)|Speedplay]] *[[SRAM (bicycles)|SRAM]] *[[Sturmey Archer]] *[[SunTour]] *[[Sugino]] *[[Syncros]] *[[Santa Cruz Bicycles|Santa Cruz]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Martin Bolland | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Martin Keith Bolland | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1956|08}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = British | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Cambridge University]] | occupation = Chairman, [[Capita]] | known for = co-founder, [[Alchemy Partners]] | boards = [[Capita]]
[[Alchemy Partners]] | salary = | networth = | spouse = | parents = | children = | relations = | website = }} '''Martin Keith Bolland''' (born August 1956) is a British businessman, the chairman of [[Capita]], and a co-founder and partner of [[Alchemy Partners]]. ==Early life== Martin Keith Bolland was born in August 1956.{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/02081330/officers |title=CAPITA PLC - Officers (free information from Companies House) |website=Beta.companieshouse.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-04-16}} He has a bachelor's degree in Economics from [[Cambridge University]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=126564&privcapId=879402 |title=List of Public Companies Worldwide, Letter - Businessweek - Businessweek |website=Bloomberg.com |date= |accessdate=2016-04-16}} He is a chartered accountant.{{cite web|url=http://www.capitareport2009.co.uk/governance/board_members.aspx |title=Board members |website=Capitareport2009.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-04-16}} ==Career== He is the chairman of [[Capita]] since January 2010, and chairman of QHotels. He is a co-founder and partner of [[Alchemy Partners]]. ==Personal life== Bolland lives in England. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bolland, Martin Keith}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Private equity and venture capital investors]]

{{Infobox person | name = Sir Martyn Arbib | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Martyn Arbib | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = | residence = | education = [[Felsted School]] | alma mater = | occupation = businessman | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relations = | website = }}
'''Sir Martyn Arbib''' is a British businessman who led the [[Perpetual plc|Perpetual]] [[asset management|fund management]] company during the late 20th century, unusually based in [[Henley-on-Thames]], rather than London.
==Early life== Born into a [[Jewish]] family, Arbib attended [[Felsted School]], Essex.<ref>William D. Rubinstein, Michael Jolles, Hilary L. Rubinstein, ''The Palgrave Dictionary of Anglo-Jewish History'', Palgrave Macmillan (2011), p. 34</ref>
==Career== He sold Perpetual to the fund manager [[AMVESCAP]] in 2001 for more than £1 billion, receiving £113m together with AMVESCAP shares worth £300m, and the company became known as [[Invesco Perpetual]]. He is a director of the Perpetual Japanese Investment Trust plc.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bloomberg|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=7998316&privcapId=2491470|accessdate=16 March 2017}}</ref>
In January 2008, Swindon Town Holdings Limited, where Arbib is an investor but not a director, took control of [[Swindon Town FC]].
==Philanthropy== The Arbib Foundation, established in 1987, sponsors schools in [[Slough]], Berkshire which include the [[Langley Academy, Slough|Langley Academy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.langleyacademy.org/pages/arbibfoundation.html|title=The Arbib Foundation|last=|first=|date=|website=The Langley Academy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=10 July 2017}}</ref>
Arbib was a major benefactor in the establishment of the [[River and Rowing Museum]] at Henley, which opened in 1998.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rrm.co.uk/topnav/info_history.htm | title=History | publisher=[[Internet]] | work=[[River and Rowing Museum]] | date=2001 | accessdate=July 19, 2011 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010523052649/http://www.rrm.co.uk/topnav/info_history.htm | archivedate=May 23, 2001}}</ref> He was knighted in 2003 for services to charities, especially in education.<ref>{{London Gazette | issue = 56963| date = 14 June 2003| supp = y}}</ref>
==Personal life== In his spare time, Arbib is interested in [[horse racing]]. His horse [[Snurge]] won the [[St. Leger Stakes]] in 1990. As well as Henley, he also has a home in [[Barbados]].
His daughter Annabel is married to businessman Paddy Nicoll.<ref name="standard1">{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/financier-offers-10m-over-the-asking-price-for-record-country-house-sale-7238427.html |title=Financier offers £10m over the asking price for record country house sale | London Evening Standard |publisher=Standard.co.uk |date=2006-08-27 |accessdate=2017-07-10}}</ref> Her father bought [[Culham Court, Berkshire|Culham Court]] for her in 1997 for £12 million, and in 2006, the Swiss-born British financier [[Urs Schwarzenbach]] bought it for £35 million, £10 million above the asking price.<ref name="standard1"/>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/richlist/person/0,,37913,00.html Rich list entry] in the ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)|Sunday Times]]'', 2005 * [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/richlist/person/0,,33770,00.html Rich list entry] in the ''Sunday Times'', 2004
{{DEFAULTSORT:Arbib, Martyn}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Felsted School]] [[Category:People from Henley-on-Thames]] [[Category:British Jews]] [[Category:Jewish philanthropists]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:British philanthropists]] [[Category:British racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox person | honorific – prefix = | name = Michael Bernard Easson | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1955|3|22}}<ref name="ANU">[http://archivescollection.anu.edu.au/index.php/michael-easson-collection Deposit Z514 – Michael Easson Collection, Noel Butlin Archives Centre, Australian National University]</ref> | birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]] | death_date = <!--{{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}}--> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | citizenship = Australian | nationality = | party = [[Australian Labor Party (New South Wales Branch)|Labor Party]] | spouse = [[Mary Easson]] | partner = <!--For those with a domestic partner and not married--> | relations = [[Shane Easson]] {{small|(twin brother)}} | children = 2 children | parents = | residence = | education = [[Sydney Technical High School]] | alma_mater = [[University of New South Wales]]; [[Campion Hall]], [[University of Oxford]]; [[Australian Defence Force Academy]] | occupation = [[Businessman]] | profession = | known_for = | religion = }}
'''Michael Bernard Easson''' [[Order of Australia|AM]] (born 22 March 1955 in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia), is an Australian [[businessman]]. On 8 June 1998 Easson was awarded Member of the [[Order of Australia]] ([[Order of Australia|AM]]).<ref>Who's Who in Australia, Edition 35, 1999.</ref>
==Career== Easson is a specialist in property and infrastructure investments.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
===Trade union related===
Easson's working career began in 1978 as a Research Assistant to the Hon. [[John Brown (Australian politician)|John Brown]] MP.<ref name="ANU"/> He then joined the [[Labor Council of New South Wales]] (now Unions NSW) as Education & Research Officer, then Assistant Secretary (1984) and Secretary (1989-1994). At the age of 34, he was elected as the youngest ever Secretary. He elected Vice President of the [[Australian Council of Trade Unions]], 1993 to 1994, and Senior Vice President of the [[Australian Labor Party (New South Wales Branch)|Labor Party (NSW Branch)]] between 1993 and 1995. Whilst at the Labor Council he was Managing Director of Radio Station [[2KY]] (1989 to 1994), and in 1989 co-founded both Asset Super (since 2012 part of CARE Super) and Chifley Financial Services. Between 1978 and 1987 Easson served as a member for the NSW Council of the Trade Union Trading Authority (TUTA).<ref name="ANU"/>
After resigning from the Labor Council in 1994, Easson pursued business, academic and other interests.
===Business related=== Easson joined the private sector in 1994, recruited by Sydney Olympic Bid Chief Rod McGeogh for law firm Corrs Chambers Westgarth, and serving on various Boards, including as an independent Director on Macquarie’s Industrial Property fund, a predecessor to the Goodman Group, the industrial property REIT. Specialising as a company director with businesses in infrastructure, construction and investment, along with Sydney businessmen Shane and Adam Geha, Easson formed EG Property, of which he is co-owner and Executive Chairman.<ref>[http://www.eg.com.au EG Funds Management]</ref>
Easson presently serves as non-Executive Chair of the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia (ASFA), Executive Director and co-owner of both EG and the building technology company Ridley & Co, and non-executive Chair of the Canberra Renewal Authority.<ref>http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/act-government-announces-board-members-for-new-land-agencies-michael-easson-and-john-fitzgerald-to-chair-20170620-gwupq4.html</ref>
In March 2017, he stepped down as Chair of Icon Water, formerly known as ACTEW Corporation, and as Chair of ActewAGL, the energy distribution and retail business in Canberra. In July 2016, Michael Easson retired as a director of ANZ Stadium.
From 2012 to 2014 he was Chair of the Ministerial Council on Business Skills Migration.<ref>New advisory council on skilled migration {{cite web |url=http://www.minister.immi.gov.au/media/cb/2012/cb188019.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121229231529/http://www.minister.immi.gov.au/media/cb/2012/cb188019.htm |archivedate=29 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Easson has served on several top 50 Australian and other boards; his experience includes as a director NSW State Superannuation Board and predecessor boards (1986-1995), the State Rail Authority of NSW (1989-1993), [[NRMA Insurance]] (1993 to 1996), Macquarie-Goodman Industrial Fund (1994-2003), Barclay Mowlem Australia (1998-2000), InTech (1998-2003), [[Macquarie Infrastructure Group]] (1996 to 2007),<ref>[http://www.macquarie.com.au/au/mig/management/aus_board.htm Macquarie Infrastructure Group Board]</ref> Kaldor family company boards in apparel, chemicals and office works (1997 to 2004), Metro Transport Sydney (2002-2006), Sydney Roads Group (2006-2007), and the [[ING Group]] Real Estate Group in Australia (2004-2012).<ref>[http://www.ingrealestate.com.au/investment/people.asp?pid=27&sectionid=152 ING Real Estate Board] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829155233/http://www.ingrealestate.com.au/investment/people.asp?pid=27&sectionid=152 |date=29 August 2007 }}</ref>
He was the inaugural Chairman of the NSW Urban Taskforce, an urban planning policy advocate group in Australia, from 2000 to 2002.
Easson was a foundation Member of the [[National Competition Council]] (1996 to 1999) and an Assistant Commissioner and Commissioner of several Productivity Reports, including the review of Work, Health and Safety in Australia (1994-1995). He served as Chairman of the Review of Commonwealth Payments to Statutory Authorities and Special Purpose Payment to the States from 1995 to 1996. According to then [[Minister for Finance (Australia)|Finance Minister]] [[John Fahey (politician)|John Fahey]] in 1997, this resulted in one-off saving of $400 million to the Australian Government.
He was Adjunct Professor of Management at the [[Australian Graduate School of Management]] from 1994 to 1998 and served as senior Vice President of [[UNICEF]] Australia from 1998 to 2002 and as a member of the Board of the [[Museum of Contemporary Art Australia|Museum of Contemporary Art]] (1999-2000) and as a Director of the [[Sydney Symphony]] (1995-1996).
==Early life and education== Michael Easson was born in Sydney on 22 March 1955. He was educated at St Declan's Primary, Marist Brothers Penshurst and he matriculated at [[Sydney Technical High School]] in 1972.<ref name="ANU"/>
Easson graduated with First Class Honours in Politics from the [[University of New South Wales]] in 1976. In 1981 he completed a Trade Union Program at the [[Harvard Business School]] and completed management and finance programs at [[Stanford Business School]] in 1997, and more recently a Masters in Science in Sustainable Development (with Distinction) from Campion Hall, University of Oxford, and a PhD in history from the Australian Defence Force Academy at the University of NSW. In 2016, Easson was awarded a second PhD in Transport and Urban Planning from the University of Melbourne.
He is married to former federal politician [[Mary Easson]] (Member for [[Division of Lowe|Lowe]], from 1993 to 1996). They have two adult daughters.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.michaeleasson.com Michael Easson Official Website]
{{S-start}} {{S-npo|union}} {{Succession box| title=Secretary of the [[Labor Council of New South Wales]] | before=[[John MacBean]] | after=[[Peter Sams]] | years=1989{{spaced ndash}}1994}} {{S-end}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category San Beda College alumni to [[:Category:San Beda University alumni]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 February 7]].
revision.text:
'''Miguel B. Varela''' (c. 1940 – 24 August 2016)<ref>[http://www.philstar.com/business/2016/08/26/1617241/miguel-varela-passes-away Miguel Varela passes away]</ref> was a Filipino businessman, [[Corporate law|corporate lawyer]], and management practitioner. He was the president and chairman of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PCCI), the largest business organization in the [[Philippines]]. He was also the president of the Employers Confederation of the Philippines (ECOP), the largest association of employers in the country.
==Education==
Varela earned an [[Associate of Arts]] degree from [[San Beda College]] and a [[Bachelor of Laws]] degree from [[Ateneo de Manila University]]. He completed the Top Management and Productivity Program at the [[Asian Institute of Management]] (AIM) and attended special courses in Managerial Management and Organizational Development, Productivity, Legal Management, Labor and Industrial Relations, Development of Small and Medium Enterprises, under sponsorship of the [[International Labour Organization]] in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]; the Asian Productivity Organization (APO) and the Nikkeren in Japan.<ref name=member>Member profile, Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PCCI). 2005.</ref>
==Business leadership==
Varela has served in various capacities as a corporate lawyer and management practitioner. He has been the President and Chairman, Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry; Chairman of the Board of HK Securities, Inc.; President of the Transunion Corporation; Director of Union Industries, Inc.; Director of Acoje Holdings, Inc.; Director of Mabuhay Vinyl Corporation; and Chairman of The Lumier Group; Vice President for Corporate Affairs of General Diesel Corporation from 1976 to 1979; Director and Vice President of ASEAN Business Corporation; and Vice President and Corporate Counsel of F.J. Elizalde and Company from 1976 to 1979; and Assistant Manager in the Planning Research and Development Office of the National Economic and Development Authority from 1966 to 1970.<ref name="member"/>
==Organizational affiliations==
Varela has been the Chairman Emeritus of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PCCI). He has been Chairman of the Trade and International Affairs Committee at the PCCI.<ref name="member"/>
He served as Chairman and President of the Employers Confederation of the Philippines (ECOP) from 1995 to 1999. He was Vice President of the ECOP in 1975.<ref name="member"/>
He has been the President of the Philippines, Inc. (formerly TEAM Philippines Foundation); and President of the Philippine Association of Voluntary Arbitration Foundation, Inc. (PHVAF).<ref name="member"/>
He has also been the Commissioner and Corporate Secretary of Streetwatch Commission and the Foundation for Crime Prevention; Vice President, Ateneo Law Alumni Foundation; and Director of the Makati Rotary Club.<ref name="member"/>
He is an active member of the [[ASEAN]] Confederation of Employers, and the Management Association of the Philippines (MAP).<ref name="member"/>
==Government==
Varela served as Member (representing Employer and Industry Sector) of the Board of Directors of the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA); Commissioner (representing the Business Sector) of the National Labor Relations Commission; Commissioner (representing employers) of the Social Security System; Member (representing Management) of the National Manpower and Youth Council; Commissioner (representing employers) of the Employees' Compensation Commission; Commissioner (representing employers) of the Occupational Safety and Health Board; and Director of the National Economic Council (now National Economic and Development Authority) from 1967 to 1972.<ref name="member"/>
==Diplomacy==
Varela was a Philippine Delegate (representing employers) to the International Labor Conference; head delegate, member, and participant in various international activities, such as the Philippine Business Delegation on the Presidential Visits to China, Malaysia, Brunei, Singapore, Japan, Indonesia, USA, New Zealand, and Hong Kong; the [[ASEAN]] Conference of Employers' Top Management; Top Management Forum on Role of New Ventures; Free Trade and Social Responsibility; and ASEAN Employers Symposium.<ref name="member"/>
Varela is an Arbiter of the International Court of Arbitration (ICC) in [[Paris]], [[France]]. He is also the Philippine Representative to the [[APEC]] Business Advisory Council; and the East Asia Business Advisory Council (EABC).<ref name="member"/>
==External links== *[http://www.pcci.org.ph Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry]
== References == {{Reflist}}
* * * *

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} The established '''nuclear industry in South Australia''' is focused on [[uranium mining]], milling and the export of uranium oxide concentrate for use in the production of nuclear fuel for [[nuclear power plant]]s. The state is home to the world's largest known single deposit of uranium, which is worked by [[BHP Billiton]] at the [[Olympic Dam mine]]. Contaminated legacy sites exist at [[Maralinga]] and [[Emu Field, South Australia|Emu Field]], where nuclear weapons tests were conducted in the 1950s and 1960s and at former uranium mines and milling sites. Nuclear waste is stored by CSIRO at [[Woomera, South Australia|Woomera]] and future waste storage prospects were considered during the deliberations of the [[Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission]] in 2016. The Commission has recommended that South Australia considers opportunities in nuclear waste storage (including developing a repository for spent nuclear fuel), the establishment of a nuclear fuel leasing scheme and the repeal of prohibitions which currently prevent future nuclear industrial development nationally. In June 2017, former Prime Minister [[Tony Abbott]] acknowledged fellow former Prime Minister [[Bob Hawke]]'s support for expanding the nuclear industry and asserted that the "Australian Labor government under Premier Jay Weatherill would like to develop new industries to supplement the uranium mine at Roxby Downs. Why not have a nuclear submarine servicing facility in that state – and the industries that would inevitably spin-off?"{{Cite web|url=https://www.cis.org.au/commentary/articles/transcript-the-hon-tony-abbot-mp-submarines-why-settle-for-second-best/|title=TRANSCRIPT. The Hon Tony Abbot MP, Submarines: why settle for second-best?|publisher=cis.org.au|access-date=30 June 2017}} == Uranium mining == [[File:Radium Hill 1954.jpg|alt=Radium Hill uranium mine (1954)|thumb|Radium Hill uranium mine (1954)]] [[Uranium mining in Australia|Uranium mining]] has occurred in [[South Australia]], since the early 20th century, when [[radium]] was the target mineral in uranium-bearing ore. During the Cold War, the [[Thomas Playford IV|Playford]] government facilitated the development of the [[Radium Hill uranium mine]] and the associated Port Pirie uranium treatment complex. These closed in the early 1960s after a seven-year contract of supply had been fulfilled. In the 1970s, the discovery of a massive uranium-bearing [[iron oxide copper gold ore deposits|IOCG orebody]] near [[Roxby Downs, South Australia|Roxby Downs]] led to the eventual opening of the Olympic Dam mine in 1988.{{Cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article110611186|title=Official opening of Roxby Downs – The Canberra Times (ACT : 1926 – 1995) – 5 Nov 1988|website=Trove|access-date=6 May 2016}} In the 2000s, the sector expanded to include [[In situ leach|in-situ leach mining]] operations at [[Beverley Uranium Mine|Beverley]], [[Four Mile uranium mine|Four Mile]] and [[Honeymoon Uranium Mine|Honeymoon]]. As of May 2016, Beverley and Honeymoon mines are in care and maintenance mode{{Cite web|url=http://www.minerals.statedevelopment.sa.gov.au/mining/mines_and_quarries|title=Mines and quarries|website=minerals.statedevelopment.sa.gov.au|access-date=6 May 2016}} owing to weak uranium prices in the wake of the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|Fukushima nuclear disaster]]. Exploration for uranium in South Australia reached a record high in 2006 with forty companies exploring for the mineral.{{Cite web|url=https://sarigbasis.pir.sa.gov.au/WebtopEw/ws/samref/sarig1/image/DDD/MESAJ080.pdf|title=20 Years of MESA Journal|website=MESA Journal 80 – 1|publisher=Government of South Australia|page=6|access-date=27 June 2016}} === Uranium export === Uranium mined in South Australia is exported, where it is used in the production of nuclear fuel for use in nuclear power plants. In 2013, uranium oxide concentrate produced in South Australia was being exported to Britain, France, Sweden, Finland, Belgium, Canada and the United States. In 2011, South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill expressed his support for exporting uranium to India, despite its status as a non-signatory to the [[Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty/Treaty text|Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2011/s3367260.htm|title=SA Premier supports uranium export to India|date=15 November 2011|access-date=4 July 2016}} By December 2015, no further barriers remained preventing such trade.{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2015/12/19/australias-nuclear-deal-with-india_n_8824564.html|title=Australia Ready For Uranium Sales To India|website=Huffington Post Australia|access-date=4 July 2016}} == Nuclear waste storage == [[File:Kevin Scarce in Adelaide, 31 May 2016.jpg|alt=Kevin Scarce in Adelaide (2016)|thumb|Kevin Scarce in Adelaide (2016)]] [[File:Rowan Ramsey (2015).jpg|thumb|Rowan Ramsey (2015)]] Concentrations of nuclear waste in South Australia exist in the tailings ponds at the Olympic Dam mine, at the site of the former Port Pirie uranium treatment works and in the tailings block at the former Radium Hill mine. [[Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation|CSIRO]] operates a nuclear waste storage facility at [[Woomera, South Australia|Woomera]] in the state's far north. Unsuccessful attempts were made by the [[Howard Government]] to establish further [[Radioactive waste|nuclear waste storage]] facilities in South Australia between 1998 and 2004.{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-09-22/a-timeline-of-south-australia's-nuclear-dump-debate/6794606|title=A timeline of South Australia's nuclear dump debate|date=22 September 2015|publisher=ABC News|access-date=6 May 2016}} A prospective nuclear waste storage site at Barndioota was announced in 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-13/government-releases-shortlist-sites-for-nuclear-waste-storage/6937244|title=Six sites shortlisted for nuclear waste storage facility|date=12 November 2015|publisher=ABC News|access-date=6 May 2016}} The property is owned by [[Grant Chapman]], and the traditional owners are the [[Adnyamathanha]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-04-29/nuclear-waste-dump-expected-south-australian-cattle-station/7369346|title=SA cattle station could be first nuclear waste dump site|date=28 April 2016|publisher=ABC News|access-date=6 May 2016}} The site is a candidate for a future National Nuclear Waste Management Facility,{{Cite web|url=http://www.radioactivewaste.gov.au/|title=National Radioactive Waste Management Facility|publisher=radioactivewaste.gov.au|dead-url=|access-date=3 September 2017}} where domestically produced nuclear waste, and repatriated, reprocessed [[spent nuclear fuel]] from Australia's research reactors at Lucas Heights would be stored. Two other candidate sites exist near [[Kimba, South Australia|Kimba]] on [[Eyre Peninsula]], and as of 2017, community consultation there is ongoing. The Kimba sites are located in the federal electorate of Grey, for which [[Rowan Ramsey|Rowan Ramsay]] is the sitting member. Ramsey has publicly advocated for the establishment of nuclear waste storage facilities in South Australia, and has stated that he would be comfortable storing it on his own property.{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/lib-mp-happy-to-store-nuclear-waste/news-story/9e93eed3f783657116093ff7d0af22a4|title=Lib MP happy to store nuclear waste|work=NewsComAu|access-date=3 September 2017|language=en}} Ramsay did not nominate his own property for the project after receiving advice that it would constitute a [[conflict of interest]]. Opinion on the benefits and risks associated with establishing a facility has divided the township of Kimba.{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/rural/2016-02-18/nuclear-dump-support-at-kimba-diifficult-to-determine/7181410|title=Kimba community divided over proposed nuclear dump|date=18 February 2016|work=ABC Rural|access-date=3 September 2017|language=en-AU}} Opponents of the establishment of a new national facility for domestically produced nuclear waste believe that such waste should be stored long-term at Lucas Heights, where much of the waste was and continues to be generated. Spokespeople for the opposition include [[Jim Green (activist)|Jim Green]] of [[Friends of the Earth Australia|Friends of the Earth]] and [[Dave Sweeney|David Sweeney]] of the [[Australian Conservation Foundation]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/kimba-votes-yes-to-radioactive-waste-dump-in-eyre-peninsula/news-story/96ca27ddaa0f67519b60a366584156bc|title=Kimba votes yes to radioactive waste dump|access-date=3 September 2017}} The prospect of storing nuclear waste in the tunnels of the Olympic Dam mine has also been speculated upon by opinion writers, politicians and the community.{{Cite web|url=http://www.themonitor.com.au/news-articles/160616-ramsey-visits-ahead-of-important-election|title=160616 – Ramsey visits ahead of 'important' Election|publisher=themonitor.com.au|access-date=17 June 2016}} Support for the development of new nuclear waste storage facilities in South Australia was expressed by the [[Committee for Adelaide]] on 6 May 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-05-06/nuclear-dump-investigation-committee-for-adelaide/7391554|title=Finland nuke trip convinces delegation to support SA waste dump plan|date=6 May 2016|publisher=ABC News|access-date=7 May 2016}} The Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission's final report, which was delivered to the Governor of South Australia on 6 May 2016 recommended the consideration of the establishment of a repository for imported spent nuclear fuel in South Australia. The report was released in full on 9 May 2016. The report was put before a Citizens Jury, which ultimately voted not to proceed with investigating the prospect of importing spent nuclear fuel for storage and disposal in South Australia. In December 2016, a group of prominent citizens signed an open letter expressing an opposing view. It stated:
"We, the undersigned, call on South Australia’s elected representatives of all parties to continue to explore this opportunity. We request further investigations into issues that a) are essential for better understanding project feasibility and b) could be investigated at relatively low cost. We call for partnership between the State Government and relevant Federal Government agencies to formally meet with prospective client nations in order to gain greater certainty and ensure we are fully informed as to the nature of this opportunity."
Signatories were: [[Fraser Ainsworth]] AM, [[Rob Chapman (businessman)|Rob Chapman]], [[Tim Cooper (brewer)|Tim Cooper]] AM, [[Di Davidson]] AM, [[Colin Dunsford]] AM, Geoff Day OAM, [[Robert Gerard]] AO, [[Ian Gould (geologist)|Ian Gould]] AM, Kathy Gramp, [[Jim Hazel]], Mike Heard, [[David Klingberg]] AO, Theo Maras AM, [[Karlene Maywald]], [[Jim McDowell]], Mike Miller AO, [[Tanya Monro]], Creagh O'Connor AM, [[Leanna Read]], Karen Reynolds, Richard Ryan AO, Antony Simpson, Michael Terlet AO, Meera Verma, Graham Walters and Stephen Young.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohscareer.com.au/archived-news/advocates-want-waste-talk-to-continue|title=Advocates want waste talk to continue|publisher=ohscareer.com.au|access-date=29 September 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/prominent-south-australians-demand-that-the-state-push-ahead-with-study-on-nuclear-waste-repository/news-story/f784dcc1328f7edca73744480c50c6a1|title=Dear SA, don't dump nuclear option|access-date=29 September 2017}} A similar letter was published in March 2017 on [[Ben Heard]]'s website, ''Bright New World''. Many of the former signatories signed again, and the following new names were added: Rick Allert AO, [[Amanda Blair]], [[Corey J. A. Bradshaw|Corey Bradshaw]], Mark Butcher, Matt Clemow, Greg Clothier, Brian Cunningham, Colin Goodall, John Heard AM, Mark Malcolm, Hon. [[Ian McLachlan]] AO, Carolyn Mitchell, Craig Mudge AO, [[Göran Roos|Goran Roos]], [[Raymond Spencer]], Lissa Van Camp, Jodie Van Deventer, Hon. [[Trish White]], [[Paul Willis (science communicator)|Paul Willis]] and [[Stephen Yarwood]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.brightnewworld.org/media/2017/3/3/an-open-letter-to-south-australias-elected-members-and-political-parties-2-march-2017|title=An open letter to South Australia's elected members and political parties 2 March 2017|work=Bright New World|access-date=29 September 2017|language=en-AU}} In March 2017, it was estimated that $30 million would need to be spent to manage nuclear waste stored at Woomera. Barrels containing the wastes were found to be rusting and deteriorating.{{Cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/deteriorating-radioactive-waste-barrels-at-woomera-require-30-million-cleanup-by-csiro/news-story/35e145b33ce748406d46d892ade39e96|title=Deteriorating radioactive waste barrels at Woomera require $30 million clean-up by CSIRO|last=Jean|first=Peter|date=14 March 2017|work=The Advertiser|access-date=3 September 2017|dead-url=}} == Nuclear weapons == A series of British [[Nuclear weapons tests in Australia|nuclear weapons tests]] were conducted at [[British nuclear tests at Maralinga|Maralinga and Emu Field]] during the 1950s and early 1960s. Land remains contaminated at these sites and access is restricted. Australia has no domestic nuclear weapons nor the capability to develop them. Australia is allied with countries which do maintain nuclear arsenals. As of 2016 the [[Liberal-National Coalition]] does not support a prospective ban on the possession of nuclear weapons, while the [[Australian Labor Party]] and [[Australian Greens]] do.{{Cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/barack-obama-goes-to-hiroshima-while-australia-stops-worrying-and-loves-the-bomb-20160525-gp3gi2.html|title=Barack Obama makes history in Hiroshima, while Australia stops worrying and loves the bomb|access-date=4 July 2016}} {{See also|British nuclear tests at Maralinga}} == Potential expansion == In 2015, a [[Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission]] was initiated by the Government of South Australia. It was tasked with investigating opportunities and risks associated with potential expansion of the state's role in the nuclear fuel cycle. Commissioner [[Kevin Scarce]] delivered its final report to the Governor of South Australia on 6 May 2016. The Commission's final report recommended the repeal of prohibitions preventing nuclear industrial development in Australia, including the legalisation of nuclear power generation. The report recommended the establishment of a facility to store international stockpiled [[spent nuclear fuel]] and the consideration of a [[nuclear fuel leasing]] scheme to accompany it. The latter was also described by the Commission as a potential enabler for future [[Enriched uranium|enrichment]] and fuel processing activities, though such further processing developments were deemed to not be feasible within the next decade. The establishment of nuclear power generation in South Australia was also deemed inappropriate given the state's high penetration of solar and wind power.{{Main|Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission}} === 2016–17 === The Government of South Australia has allocated $3.6 million to the [[Department of the Premier and Cabinet (South Australia)|Department of the Premier and Cabinet]] for 2016–17 "to enable the government to engage with the community to develop an informed response to the Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission Final Report."{{Cite book|url=http://servicesa.cdn.on.net/budget201617/pdfs/budget/2016-17_budget_measures_statement.pdf|title=2016–17 STATE BUDGET – Budget Paper 5 – Budget Measures Statement|last=|first=|publisher=Government of South Australia|year=2016|isbn=|location=Adelaide, South Australia|pages=69–70|issn=1440-8589}} ==== Citizens' Jury process ==== [[File:Nigel McBride, Business SA at CEDA event in Adelaide (2016).jpg|alt=Nigel McBride, Business SA|thumb|Nigel McBride, Business SA]] Following the conclusion of the Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission, the Department of the Premier and Cabinet established a "YourSAy nuclear?" website, advertising campaign and Citizens' Jury process. Managed by the [[New Democracy Foundation]], the Citizens' Jury process randomly invited 25,000 South Australians to participate by post. Of those who accepted the invitation, a total of 350 jurors will be chosen to meet and discuss the Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission's final report, help produce a simplified version for further discussion, and ultimately express their support or rejection of its various recommendations. South Australian company DemocracyCo won the contract to facilitate the first Citizens' Jury. DemocracyCo spokesperson Emily Jenke described the process and its result as "one of the pieces the Premier and Government will be using to inform their thinking".{{Cite web|url=http://indaily.com.au/news/local/2016/06/03/nuclear-jury-about-the-big-picture-not-manufacturing-consent/|title=Nuclear jury about the big picture, not manufacturing consent – InDaily|date=3 June 2016|website=InDaily|access-date=17 June 2016}} The first Citizens' Jury was composed of 50 people. They were provided with the Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission's final report and heard from a panel whose members are listed below.{{Cite web|url=http://indaily.com.au/news/local/2016/06/23/a-businessman-and-environmentalist-and-an-oncologist-walked-into-a-citizens-jury/|title=A businessman, an environmentalist and an oncologist walked into a citizens' jury... – InDaily|date=23 June 2016|website=InDaily|access-date=23 June 2016}} {| class="wikitable" !Member's Name !Primary Position Held !Other Relevant
Affiliations |- |Jason Kuchel |CEO of [[South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy|South Australian Chamber of Mines & Energy]] |Member of [[Minerals and Energy Advisory Council]] |- |Simon Longstaff |Founder of [[The Ethics Centre]] |Financial supporters of The Ethics Centre include [[BHP Billiton]] and [[Santos Limited|Santos Ltd]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.ethics.org.au/about/our-supporters|title=The Ethics Centre – The Ethics Centre|publisher=ethics.org.au|access-date=23 June 2016}} |- |[[Nigel McBride]] |CEO of Business SA |Member of the State Advisory Council of the [[Committee for Economic Development of Australia]] (CEDA), former lawyer with [[MinterEllison]] |- |Michael Penniment |Director of [[Radiation oncology]] at the [[Royal Adelaide Hospital]] |Employee of the Government of South Australia |- |[[Leanna Read]] |Chief Scientist of SA |Member of [[Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission]] Expert Advisory and Medical Expert Advisory committees, member of the [[Economic Development Board (South Australia)|Economic Development Board]] of South Australia, Fellow of the [[Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering]] and Chair of the [[South Australian Science Council]] |- |Kelly-Anne Saffin |CEO of Northern and Yorke Regional Development Australia |RDA is funded by the [[Government of Australia]] and the Government of South Australia{{Cite web|url=http://www.yorkeandmidnorth.com.au/about_us/role_structure/|title=Regional Development Yorke and Mid North – Role & Structure|last=North|first=Regional Development Australia Yorke and Mid|website=Regional Development Australia Yorke and Mid North|access-date=23 June 2016}} |- |Keith Thomas |CEO of SA Native Title Services |SA Native Title Services is funded by the [[Government of South Australia]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.nativetitlesa.org/about/overview|title=Overview|publisher=nativetitlesa.org|access-date=23 June 2016}} |- |Craig Wilkins |CEO of [[Conservation Council of South Australia]] |Wilkins is former Chief of Staff of [[Australian Greens]] MLC [[Mark Parnell]]. The Conservation Council of South Australia receives funding from the Government of South Australia. |} [[File:Know Nuclear campaign bus shelter advertisement, South Australia, August 2016.jpg|alt=Know Nuclear campaign bus shelter advertisement, August 2016|thumb|Know Nuclear campaign bus shelter advertisement, August 2016]] The first Citizens Jury produced a report after hearing witnesses and deliberating over four sitting days. Its publication was followed by the launch of a statewide community consultation program coordinated by the Department of the Premier and Cabinet. The campaign carried the slogan "Get to know nuclear. Discover. Discuss. Decide" and included print, radio and television commercials, online discussions and community displays attended by DPC staff. A second jury was later formed, expanding the cohort of jurors to approximately 350 people. After hearing from a larger cohort of expert witnesses, the citizens' jury ultimately concluded, by a two-thirds majority vote, to not pursue to prospect of the importation of spent nuclear fuel to South Australia under any circumstances. A "lack of trust" was cited as a primary driver.{{Cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/citizens-jury-overwhelmingly-rejects-nuclear-waste-storage-facility-for-south-australia/news-story/8340c103234775fffcf9b88b2aea6906|title='No decision' on nuclear waste plan: Weatherill|access-date=30 June 2017}} === Nuclear submarines === [[File:Barracuda-Suffren.svg|alt=Profile of the Barracuda type submarine, with her pump-jet propeller and X-shaped stern planes.|thumb|Profile of the Barracuda type submarine, with her pump-jet propeller and X-shaped stern planes.]] The prospect of constructing nuclear submarines in South Australia has been raised on various occasions during the 2010s. In 2011, the CEO of [[Defence SA]], [[Andrew Fletcher (businessman)|Andrew Fletcher]] expressed his personal view that it would be unlikely for Australia's Future Submarine project to commit to producing nuclear powered submarines, unless a nuclear industry was established in Australia beforehand, or if their production was outsourced offshore. He expressed his belief that a commitment to 12 diesel-powered submarines was more likely.{{Cite web|url=http://www.australiandefence.com.au/news/from-the-source-andrew-fletcher-chief-executive-officer-of-defence-sa|title=From The Source: Andrew Fletcher Chief Executive Officer of Defence SA|access-date=3 August 2016}} Authors from [[UCL Australia]] have written opinion pieces and produced research papers on the topic. In 2016, the contract for the supply of Australia's Future Submarines Project was awarded to French company [[Direction des Constructions Navales Services]] (DCNS), and the [[French Barracuda-class submarine|Barracuda-class submarine]] was selected. The Barracuda-class submarine is currently a [[Nuclear submarine|nuclear powered submarine]], but the Australian Government has sought a modified design with diesel-powered pump jet propulsion. The other bidders which were competing for the tender do not make nuclear powered submarines. Australian Cabinet ministers have discussed the merits of keeping the nuclear propulsion option open by choosing the Barracuda-class design and the coalition government is supportive of nuclear industrial development in Australia.{{Cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/business/manufacturing/coalition-plans-nuclearpowered-submarine-fleet-over-long-term-20160429-goieal|title=Coalition plans nuclear-powered submarine fleet over long term|date=1 May 2016|website=Financial Review|access-date=18 June 2016}} In 2015, former [[Rolls-Royce Holdings|Rolls Royce]] [[Nuclear engineering|nuclear engineer]] and submarine expert [[Steve Ludlam (engineer)|Steve Ludlam]] was appointed to the [[Defence SA Advisory Board]]. in 2017, former Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott spoke of the merits of considering nuclear propulsion for Australia's Future Submarine Project, claiming various advantages over diesel propulsion, including range and speed. [[File:Jason Kuchel, Chief Executive, South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy (2015).jpg|alt=Jason Kuchel, South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy|thumb|Jason Kuchel, South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy]] === Support === Support for expanding the nuclear industry in South Australia has been expressed by corporate uranium mining interests [[WMC Resources|Western Mining Corporation]] (the first owners of the Olympic Dam mine), BHP Billiton (their successors){{Cite web|url=http://nuclearrc.sa.gov.au/app/uploads/2016/03/BHP-Billiton-03-08-2015.pdf|title=Submission to the Royal Commission into the Nuclear Fuel Cycle|date=8 March 2015|website=|publisher=BHP Billiton|access-date=7 May 2016}} and the [[Rio Tinto Group]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/a-nuclear-australia-is-inevitable-rio-chairman-20110505-1ea83.html|title=A nuclear Australia is inevitable: Rio chairman|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=7 May 2016}} Industry representative bodies have also expressed their support, including the [[Minerals Council of Australia]] and its predecessors, the [[Uranium Information Centre]] and the [[Australian Uranium Association]]. Other spokespeople supporting nuclear industrial development in South Australia include [[Richard Yeeles]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-02-16/nuclear-waste-has-potential-to-earn-sa-billions-ziggy-switkowski/6115694|title=Nuclear waste dump could earn SA billions of dollars: Switkowski|date=16 February 2015|publisher=ABC News|access-date=7 May 2016}} [[Nigel McBride]] from Business SA and Jason Kuchel from the [[South Australian Chamber of Mines & Energy|South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy]]. Staff and students of [[UCL Australia]] have published research papers supporting the exploration of further nuclear industrial development in South Australia. Professor [[Stefaan Simons]] has advocated for the consideration of uranium enrichment{{Cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/business/nuclear-enrichment-industry-could-lead-to-multibilliondollar-economic-bonanza-study-says/story-fni6uma6-1226699572009|title=Nuclear enrichment industry could lead to multi-billion-dollar economic bonanza, study says|last=Hough|first=Andrew|date=18 August 2013|newspaper=The Advertiser|access-date=4 July 2016}} and nuclear-powered submarines. In March 2017, eleven members of the [[Turnbull Government]] were listed as openly supporting the prospect of [[nuclear power in Australia]]. Listed politicians were: [[Andrew Broad]], [[James Paterson (Australian politician)|James Paterson]], [[Tony Pasin]], [[Tim Wilson (Australian politician)|Tim Wilson]], [[Chris Back]], [[Craig Kelly (politician)|Craig Kelly]], [[Eric Abetz]], [[Andrew Hastie (politician)|Andrew Hastie]], [[Warren Entsch]], [[Bridget McKenzie]] and Rowan Ramsey.{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/put-nuclear-in-the-energy-mix-coalition-mps-tell-malcolm-turnbull-20170315-guylds.html|title=Put nuclear in the energy mix, Coalition MPs tell Malcolm Turnbull|last=Massola|first=James|date=15 March 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=3 September 2017|last2=Gartrell|first2=Adam|language=en-US}} === Opposition === There has been considerable Australian resistance to [[uranium mining]] for some decades. There have been concerns that uranium drives the global nuclear weapons cycle, disturbs or degrades [[sacred sites]], releases carcinogenic [[radon gas]], and contaminates [[groundwater]]. Nuclear power is considered by opponents as an unsafe, centralised, and secretive energy option, which creates security risks. [[High-level radioactive waste management]] has also been another major concern.Marty Branagan. [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/IntJlRuralLawP/2014/4.pdf The Australian Movement against Uranium Mining: Its Rationale and Evolution], ''International Journal of Rural Law and policy'', 2014. Opponents to the expansion of nuclear industry in South Australia include the [[Australian Greens]] (whose spokespeople include [[Scott Ludlam]] and [[Mark Parnell]]), [[Friends of the Earth Australia|Friends of the Earth]], the [[Australian Conservation Foundation]] and the [[Conservation Council of South Australia]]. Opposition has also been expressed by Kevin Buzzacott, [[Eileen Kampakuta Brown]], [[Eileen Wani Wingfield]] and other elders of several indigenous peoples. The Desert Liberation Front has coordinated protest events at the gates of the Olympic Dam mine in 2012 and 2016 using the names The Lizard's Revenge and The Lizard Bites Back.{{Cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/sa-police-close-olympic-way-as-antiuranium-protesters-light-bonfire-in-the-middle-of-the-road/news-story/691b23d3a7991cf5b1b9688a1702de45|title=SA Police close Olympic Way as anti-uranium protesters light bonfire in the middle of the road|last=Jones|first=Erin|date=3 July 2016|newspaper=The Advertiser|access-date=3 July 2016}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:South Australia]] [[Category:Nuclear industry]] [[Category:Industry in Australia]]

{{Infobox company |name = OIL -now Vistra |industry = [[Professional services]] |key_people = Jonathon Clifton
(Group Managing Director),
Simon Filmer
(Deputy Group Managing Director),
Ernest Zheng
(Managing Director, China),
Helen Soh
(Managing Director, Singapore),
Nadine Feng
(Managing Director, Taiwan),
Effy Yeung
(Executive Director, Hong Kong),
Jessica Far
(Executive Director, Hong Kong) |services = International incorporations, post incorporation technical support, on-going corporate services. |num_employees = 3000 employees(''June 2017'') |foundation = 1986 |location = [[Hong Kong]] |homepage = {{URL|vistra.com}} }} In 2017 OIL rebranded as '''[[Vistra]]''', becoming part of the Company Formation division. '''Vistra''' provides a broad range of services and solutions. Vistra employs over 3000 employees in 73 offices across 44 jurisdictions. ==History== OIL was established in Hong Kong 1986 and quickly grew its service offerings and expanded its geographic coverage. In 2011 OIL merged with '''Vistra''' before completely rebranding to Vistra in 2017. ==Offshore 2020== The [https://www.vistra.com/insights/vistra-2020 '''Offshore''' '''2020'''] was annual market research conducted by OIL. The research focused on the key trends and future developments of the offshore and related industries, and reviewed issues such as market drivers and constraints, impact of the increasing regulations and jurisdictional popularity. The last Offshore 2020 was published in December 2015. In 2017 Offshore 2020 was rebranded as Vistra 2020. Previous Publications: * “Looking forward: An industry on the move”,{{cite news|url=http://www.mondaq.com/content/pr_article.asp?pr_id=8652|title=Looking forward: An industry on the move|date=17 November 2014}} 2014 edition * “Perception and Reality: Forces driving the offshore industry”,{{cite news|url=http://www.economic-s.ru/index.php/author-articles/finances/offshore-2020-perception-and-reality-forces-driving-the-offshore-industry-report|title=Offshore 2020. Perception and Reality: Forces driving the offshore industry Report|date=28 November 2013|accessdate=9 July 2014|newspaper=Economic-s}} 2013 edition * “Opportunities and Challenges Facing the Offshore Industry”,{{cite news|url=http://www.chinaoffshore.com.hk/smoke-mirrors-and-offshore-regulation.html|title=Smoke, Mirrors and Offshore Regulation|date=3 April 2013|accessdate=9 July 2014|newspaper=China Offshore}} 2012 edition * “Insights into future trends and structure of the offshore industry”, 2011 edition * "Insights into the evolution of offshore financial services in the region and what is driving it, 2010 edition ==See also== * [[Vistra]] * [[Offshore Financial Centre]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.vistra.com/ Vistra official website] [[Category:Companies of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Offshore finance]] [[Category:Financial services companies of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Service companies of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Companies established in 1986]] [[Category:Market research]]
